title: Sydney home auctions: Inner west fixer upper sells for $2.35 million
text:
The owners of a rundown home in Strathfield walked away with a price more than $450,000 above what they would have been happy to accept at auction.

The four-bedroom house at 27 Swan St sold under the hammer at an early morning auction Saturday for $2.35 million after attracting an opening bid of $1.8 million.

And although the reserve price was undisclosed, selling agent Steven Devine reported the vendors would have been happy with $1.9 million considering the home was set on a smaller block for the area.

MORE: Suburbs tipped for surge in sales

Australia’s most amazing auction homes

The interior was also dated and the 574sqm property was in need of plenty of “tender loving care”, Mr Devine said.

The Devine Real Estate founder estimated a renovator would have needed to spend more than $100,000 to update the home.

The vendors had used the house as an investment property for at least a decade, last renting it for $800 per week, CoreLogic records showed.

“It was a great result for the size,” Mr Devine said. “On a cost per square metre basis it was much higher than the average for the area.

“The price probably reflects the future growth potential more than anything else. It’s a growth area and what today might seem like over the top will be good value down the line.”

Four buyers registered for the auction but only two took an active part — an investor and a couple hoping to occupy the property.

Auctioneer Michael Carolan said there was a “nervous” energy at the start of the sale but this quickly disappeared once the bidders had made a few offers.

The bids went up in initial increments of $25,000 before slowing to $20,000 and $10,000 increases once bidding passed the $2 million mark.

The investor was the more aggressive of the bidders, attempting a knockout bid of $2.3 million after the couple offered $2.26 million. It didn’t deter the couple initially, but when a later $2.25 million bid was upped by $10,000 they declared themselves out of contention for the home and the investor was declared the new owner.

The property was one of nearly 540 Sydney homes to go under the hammer yesterday in what was a more subdued day for sales compared to last weekend when there more than 700 auctions.

In nearby inner west suburb Lewisham, a five-bedroom Queen Anne Federation house on Gould Ave sold under the hammer for $2.731 million, beating the reserve price by $431,000.

Auctioneer and selling agent Shad Hassen of The Agency-Inner West said the auction was competitive from the start.

The opening bid was $2.6 million, well above the $2.3 million price guide. Two more buyers put their hands up to bid, but the opening bidder emerged victorious.

“It’s a beautiful home and we had a full backyard of people coming to see the auction,” Mr Hassen said.

Mr Hassen had earlier in the day sold a three-bedroom terrace in Petersham, dropping the hammer at $1.75 million, $200,000 over reserve.

The reserve for the house on Terminus St was $1.55 million and the price guide was $1.5 million to $1.6 million. The buyers were a local family.

“The home is in a row of terraces within one of Petersham’s best pockets,” Mr Hassen said. “Few properties ever come up for sale there.”

MORE: How renters are saving $150 per week

Strathfield mansion has life-size cow

But not all sellers beat their reserves at auction. A luxury home on Northcote Rd in Glebe passed in on a vendor bid of $3.6 million after attracting the interest of five registered bidders.

There was a crowd of about 80 people there to watch the auction and selling agency Belle Property-Annandale said the home would likely sell in a post-auction negotiation.
description: They offered a rundown home on a small block for their neighbourhood, but the sellers of a Sydney fixer upper managed to walk away with an unlikely multimillion-dollar price at auction today.
